questions.title: OOP Basics
questions.prompt: Explain Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) in simple terms and name its main ideas.
followups: What is a class?
What is an object?
Give a simple real-world example.

questions.title: Class vs Object
questions.prompt: What is the difference between a class and an object?
followups: Give a simple example using a 'Car' or 'Student'.
Why do we create objects from classes?
What does an object store?

questions.title: Encapsulation (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is encapsulation and why is it useful?
followups: What is a private field in simple terms?
How does encapsulation prevent mistakes?
Give a simple example.

questions.title: Abstraction (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is abstraction? Explain it using a simple example.
followups: Why does abstraction make code easier to use?
What is an example of hiding details?
What is one sign of a confusing abstraction?

questions.title: Inheritance (Basic Idea)
questions.prompt: What is inheritance in OOP? Explain it with an easy example.
followups: What is a parent/base class?
What is a child/derived class?
When can inheritance be helpful?

questions.title: Composition (Basic Idea)
questions.prompt: What does it mean to build one class using another class (composition)?
followups: Give a simple example (e.g., Car has an Engine).
Why can composition be flexible?
How is this different from inheritance?

questions.title: Interface (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is an interface? Explain why teams use interfaces.
followups: What is the main purpose of an interface?
Give a simple example (e.g., IShape).
How can interfaces help testing?

questions.title: Abstract Class (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is an abstract class and why might you use it?
followups: What does 'cannot be instantiated' mean?
Give a simple example.
When would you choose an abstract class?

questions.title: API Basics
questions.prompt: What is an API? Explain it in simple terms and give an example.
followups: Why do apps use APIs?
What is JSON often used for?
What makes an API easy to use?

questions.title: REST Basics (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is a REST API? Explain using a simple example like users or products.
followups: What does GET do?
What does POST do?
Name one common HTTP status code and meaning.

questions.title: GET vs POST (Simple)
questions.prompt: Explain the difference between GET and POST in simple terms.
followups: When would you use GET?
When would you use POST?
What data usually goes in the body?

questions.title: Debugging First Steps
questions.prompt: Your program crashes. What are the first things you check?
followups: What error message would you look for?
How do you reproduce the issue?
What is one simple fix you try first?

questions.title: Logging (Basics)
questions.prompt: What is logging and why is it useful when debugging?
followups: What is one example of a good log message?
Why not log sensitive data?
How can logs help in production?

questions.title: Exceptions (Basic Understanding)
questions.prompt: What is an exception in programming, and why do we handle exceptions?
followups: Give a simple example of an exception.
What happens if you don't handle it?
What is a try/catch in simple terms?

questions.title: Unit Testing (Purpose)
questions.prompt: What is unit testing and why do teams write unit tests?
followups: What is one thing a unit test checks?
Why test more than one input?
What is one benefit of automated tests?

questions.title: Test Cases (Easy)
questions.prompt: How do you choose simple test cases for a function?
followups: What is an edge case?
Give an example of a good test case.
Why include an empty input test?

questions.title: Version Control (Basics)
questions.prompt: What is version control and why is it important?
followups: What is a commit?
What is a branch?
Why do teams use pull requests?

questions.title: Pull Requests (Basics)
questions.prompt: What is a pull request and why do teams use it?
followups: What do code reviews help with?
What is one sign of a good PR?
How do you respond to review comments?

questions.title: Merge Conflicts (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is a merge conflict and how do you resolve it in a safe way?
followups: Why do merge conflicts happen?
What is one safe way to avoid them?
What do you do after resolving a conflict?

questions.title: Clean Code (Basics)
questions.prompt: What does 'clean code' mean to you? Name a few simple practices.
followups: Why are clear names important?
Why keep functions small?
How do comments help (and hurt)?

questions.title: Refactoring (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is refactoring? Give an example of a small refactor.
followups: Why refactor if the code works?
When should you avoid refactoring?
How do tests help refactoring?

questions.title: Data Structures: Array (Easy)
questions.prompt: What is an array and when is it useful?
followups: What is one benefit of arrays?
What is one downside?
Give a simple example.

questions.title: Data Structures: List (Easy)
questions.prompt: What is a list and how is it different from a fixed-size array?
followups: Why are lists flexible?
Give a simple example.
When would you choose a list?

questions.title: Hash Map (Simple Use)
questions.prompt: What is a hash map and what problem does it solve?
followups: Give an example like counting items.
What is a key and value?
Why is it useful in real apps?

questions.title: Stack (Simple Use)
questions.prompt: What is a stack? Explain using a real-life example.
followups: What does LIFO mean?
Where have you seen stacks used?
Why is undo a common example?

questions.title: Queue (Simple Use)
questions.prompt: What is a queue? Explain using a real-life example.
followups: What does FIFO mean?
Where are queues used in software?
How is it different from a stack?

questions.title: Linked List (High Level)
questions.prompt: What is a linked list and how is it different from an array (high level)?
followups: What is a node?
Why does memory layout matter?
When might a linked list be used?

questions.title: Big-O (Very Simple)
questions.prompt: In plain English, what does Big-O help you understand about code?
followups: Why does it matter as data grows?
When is a simple solution good enough?
Give a real-life example of something scaling.

questions.title: String vs Integer
questions.prompt: What is the difference between a string and an integer? Give examples.
followups: Why does type matter?
What happens if you try to add a string and an integer?
Give a practical example from an app.

questions.title: Null / None (Basics)
questions.prompt: What does null (or None) mean in programming? Why is it important?
followups: What bugs can null cause?
How can you prevent null errors?
Give a simple example.

questions.title: Frontend vs Backend
questions.prompt: Explain the difference between frontend and backend.
followups: Which part does the user see?
Which part stores data?
How do they communicate?

questions.title: Database Basics
questions.prompt: What is a database and why do apps use databases?
followups: What is a table?
What is a row?
Give an example of data an app might store.

questions.title: SQL vs NoSQL (Simple)
questions.prompt: What is one simple difference between SQL and NoSQL databases?
followups: When might you choose SQL?
When might you choose NoSQL?
What is a simple example of each?

questions.title: Authentication vs Authorization
questions.prompt: Explain authentication vs authorization using a simple example.
followups: Which one is login?
Which one is permissions?
Why does this matter in apps?

questions.title: Password Safety (Basics)
questions.prompt: Name a few simple best practices for handling passwords in an app.
followups: Why shouldn't you store plain text passwords?
What is hashing in simple terms?
Why use multi-factor authentication?

questions.title: Caching (Simple Idea)
questions.prompt: What is caching and why can it make apps faster?
followups: Give a simple real-world caching example.
What is one risk of caching?
Where might caching be used?

questions.title: Concurrency (Very Simple)
questions.prompt: In simple terms, what does it mean for a program to do two things at once?
followups: Give a real-life example.
Why can concurrency cause bugs?
What is one way teams reduce risk?

questions.title: Communication: Explaining a Bug
questions.prompt: How would you explain a bug you found to a teammate clearly?
followups: What details should you include?
Why include steps to reproduce?
What screenshots or logs might help?

questions.title: Collaboration: Asking for Help
questions.prompt: Describe how you ask for help when you are stuck on a technical problem.
followups: What do you try before asking?
How do you describe what you already attempted?
How do you apply the help you receive?

questions.title: Learning Quickly
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you learned a new tool or concept quickly.
followups: How did you structure your learning?
How did you validate your understanding?
What result did you achieve?

questions.title: Handling Feedback (Easy)
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you received feedback on your work and what you did with it.
followups: What was the feedback?
How did you respond?
What changed after that?

questions.title: Teamwork (Easy)
questions.prompt: Describe a time you worked on a team project. What was your role and what was the outcome?
followups: How did you divide the work?
How did you keep everyone aligned?
What did you learn?

questions.title: Conflict (Easy)
questions.prompt: Describe a small disagreement in a team and how it was resolved.
followups: What was the disagreement about?
How did you communicate?
What was the result?

questions.title: Time Management
questions.prompt: How do you manage your time when you have multiple tasks to complete?
followups: How do you prioritize tasks?
How do you track progress?
What do you do if you're behind?

questions.title: User-Focused Thinking
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you built or improved something for users.
followups: Who were the users?
What problem did you solve?
How did you know it helped?

questions.title: Why Microsoft?
questions.prompt: Why do you want to intern at Microsoft? Mention a product, team area, or value that motivates you.
followups: What Microsoft product do you use most?
What would you like to learn during the internship?
How does Microsoft align with your goals?

questions.title: What Do You Want to Learn?
questions.prompt: What are 2 or 3 skills you want to grow during this internship, and how will you work on them?
followups: How do you learn new tech quickly?
How do you handle being stuck?
How do you balance learning with delivering results?

questions.title: Polymorphism (Simple Idea)
questions.prompt: What is polymorphism in OOP? Explain it with a simple example.
followups: What does 'many forms' mean?
How do interfaces enable polymorphism?
Give an example using shapes or animals.

questions.title: Method Overloading
questions.prompt: What is method overloading? When might you use it?
followups: How is it different from overriding?
Give a simple example like calculating area.
Why is this convenient for developers?

questions.title: Method Overriding
questions.prompt: What is method overriding and why is it useful in inheritance?
followups: What does @Override or virtual mean?
Give an example with a base class and derived class.
How does this enable polymorphism?

questions.title: Constructor Basics
questions.prompt: What is a constructor and what is its purpose?
followups: When is a constructor called?
What is a default constructor?
What is constructor overloading?

questions.title: Static vs Instance Members
questions.prompt: What is the difference between static and instance members (fields/methods)?
followups: When would you make something static?
How do you access static vs instance members?
Give a simple example like Math.PI.

questions.title: Value Type vs Reference Type
questions.prompt: What is the difference between a value type and a reference type?
followups: Give examples of each in C#/Java.
Where are they stored?
How does assignment behave differently?

questions.title: Pass by Value vs Pass by Reference
questions.prompt: Explain the difference between pass by value and pass by reference.
followups: What happens to the original variable?
Give an example where this matters.
How does C#/Java handle this?

questions.title: What is .NET?
questions.prompt: What is .NET? Explain it at a high level.
followups: What is the difference between .NET Framework and .NET Core?
What languages run on .NET?
What is the CLR?

questions.title: What is C#?
questions.prompt: What is C# and what kinds of applications can you build with it?
followups: How is C# different from Java?
What are some key features of C#?
Why does Microsoft use C#?

questions.title: What is Azure?
questions.prompt: What is Microsoft Azure? Describe it in simple terms.
followups: What is cloud computing?
Give an example of an Azure service.
Why do companies use Azure?

questions.title: Windows vs Linux (Basic)
questions.prompt: What is one major difference between Windows and Linux operating systems?
followups: Why does Microsoft support Linux now?
What is WSL?
When might you choose one over the other?

questions.title: What is Visual Studio?
questions.prompt: What is Visual Studio and what is it used for?
followups: How is it different from VS Code?
What features make it useful for developers?
What have you built with it?

questions.title: What is GitHub?
questions.prompt: What is GitHub and why is it important for developers?
followups: Why did Microsoft acquire GitHub?
What is a repository?
How do you contribute to open source on GitHub?

questions.title: SOLID: Single Responsibility
questions.prompt: What is the Single Responsibility Principle? Give a simple example.
followups: Why is it better to have one reason to change?
What problems happen when a class does too much?
How do you identify violations?

questions.title: SOLID: Open-Closed
questions.prompt: What does it mean for code to be 'open for extension, closed for modification'?
followups: Give a simple example using interfaces.
Why is this important for maintainability?
How does this reduce bugs?

questions.title: SOLID: Liskov Substitution
questions.prompt: Explain the Liskov Substitution Principle in simple terms.
followups: What does 'subtypes must be substitutable for their base types' mean?
Give an example of a violation (square vs rectangle).
Why does this matter in inheritance?

questions.title: SOLID: Interface Segregation
questions.prompt: What is the Interface Segregation Principle?
followups: Why are smaller, focused interfaces better?
Give an example of a 'fat' interface problem.
How does this relate to the Single Responsibility Principle?

questions.title: SOLID: Dependency Inversion
questions.prompt: Explain the Dependency Inversion Principle in simple terms.
followups: What does it mean to depend on abstractions, not concretions?
How does dependency injection help?
Why does this make code more testable?

questions.title: Dependency Injection (Concept)
questions.prompt: What is dependency injection in simple terms?
followups: Why does this make code easier to test?
Give an example without DI and with DI.
How does constructor injection work?

questions.title: IDisposable / Dispose Pattern
questions.prompt: What is the purpose of IDisposable in .NET?
followups: What resources need explicit cleanup?
What is a using statement?
What happens if you don't dispose?

questions.title: What is Garbage Collection?
questions.prompt: Explain garbage collection in simple terms.
followups: How does it help developers?
What is a managed language?
What are common GC optimizations?

questions.title: Boxing and Unboxing
questions.prompt: What is boxing and unboxing in .NET/C#?
followups: Why can this impact performance?
Give an example.
How do generics help avoid boxing?

questions.title: IEnumerable vs IEnumerator
questions.prompt: What is the difference between IEnumerable and IEnumerator?
followups: What does foreach work with?
How does yield return work?
When would you implement these interfaces?

questions.title: Collections: List vs Dictionary
questions.prompt: When would you use a List vs a Dictionary?
followups: What is the lookup time for each?
What if you need to store unique keys?
Give a practical example for each.

questions.title: Collections: Stack vs Queue
questions.prompt: When would you choose a Stack over a Queue?
followups: Give a real-world example for each.
What are the primary operations?
How do their orders differ?

questions.title: Exception Handling: try-catch-finally
questions.prompt: Explain the purpose of try, catch, and finally blocks.
followups: What code belongs in finally?
What happens if you don't catch an exception?
When would you use multiple catch blocks?

questions.title: Checked vs Unchecked
questions.prompt: What are checked and unchecked contexts in C#?
followups: What is integer overflow?
When would you enable checked?
Why would you disable it?

questions.title: const vs readonly
questions.prompt: What is the difference between const and readonly in C#?
followups: When is each evaluated?
Can a const be a reference type?
When would you choose readonly?

questions.title: String vs StringBuilder
questions.prompt: Why is StringBuilder more efficient for many string operations?
followups: Why are strings immutable?
When should you use StringBuilder?
When is regular string concatenation fine?

questions.title: var vs explicit type
questions.prompt: When would you use var vs explicitly declaring the type?
followups: What does var mean in C#?

questions.title: Microsoft Product: Visual Studio Code
